title: 111_s3366
content: The "Firearm-Free Airport Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes findings related to firearms in airports. Congress finds that commercial airports are crucial to the US economy, with commercial aviation contributing significantly to the GDP and employing millions of people. It is essential for the safe movement of people and goods as a vital channel of interstate commerce. Individuals and terrorist organizations use commercial airports and aircraft for politically motivated violence. The 9/11 attacks had a severe impact on the US economy, resulting in casualties, property damage, and business disruptions. Firearms are prohibited in airport sterile areas under US law. Congress must regulate firearms in commercial airport facilities to ensure aviation safety, protect passengers and goods, and maintain economic stability in the industry. Prohibition on possession of firearms in certain airport buildings and airfields. Prohibition on possession of firearms at commercial airports, including terminal buildings, adjacent areas, airfields, and buildings opening onto airfields. Exceptions include authorized individuals, active duty Armed Forces members, and individuals bringing firearms into an airport. Individuals bringing firearms into a commercial airport solely to check them in checked baggage are exempt from the prohibition. Violators face up to 10 years in prison or fines. Definitions include commercial airport, firearm, and sterile area. The term 'sterile area' is defined in section 1540.5 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 463 of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 4. Signs warning of prohibition on possession of firearms in airport terminal buildings. The Secretary of Transportation will ensure signs are posted in airport terminal buildings to warn passengers of the prohibition on firearms possession.
